The JUDGES toll the knell of BURDETT'S fame,</br>The rabble rout disperse with lack of glee;</br>The Counsel homeward plod just as they came,</br>And leave the Hall to darkness and to me.
Now fades each fairy prospect on my sight;</br>All nature now appears to make a pause,</br>Save where the wits the Chronicle who write</br>Weave drowsy paragraphs to patch my cause.
Beneath those ancient walls, once vocal made</br>By vote of thanks, which late I found so cheap,</br>Indignant JUSTICE bids my laurels fade,</br>The dull copartners of my folly weep.
For me no more the flaming press shall teem,</br>Nor busy printers ply their evening care,</br>No patriots flock to propagate my theme,</br>Nor lick my feet the ill-got wreath to share.
The fulsome strain of incense-breathing puff,</br>The snuffman balling to the throng misled;</br>COBBETT'S foul Register, nor all the stuff</br>Of weekly scribes, can raise my drooping head.
Oft did the thoughtless to their judgments yield,</br>Their railings oft disloyal rage provoke;</br>How jocund each his secret soul reveal'd,</br>How laugh'd the crowd at ev'ry hackney'd joke!
Now, you ye loyal, fix on them the fault,</br>If memory to my name no trophies raise,</br>Where in the ample page with zeal unbought,</br>The pen historic gives the meed of praise.
Can golden box, tho' worth a hundred pounds,</br>Back to poor BURDETT bring his forfeit fame?</br>Can honour's voice now on his side be found,</br>Or flattery shield him from contempt and shame?
The boast of popularity's short hour,</br>And all that faction gains by means most base,</br>Await alike exposure, dreaded power,</br>The paths of folly lead but to disgrace.
Yes; still my name to rescue from neglect,</br>Some frail memorials that on bookstalls lie,</br>With uncouth rhymes and shapeless sculpture deck'd,</br>Implore the passing tribute of a sigh.
For who, to dumb forgetfulness a prey,</br>Such pleasing transient laurels e'er resign'd,</br>Left his proud height, the idol of a day,</br>Nor cast one longing, ling'ring look behind?
On some frail prop sedition still relies,</br>Some pious souls its frustrate arm admires,</br>E'en from the grave its fetid stench will rise,</br>E'en in its ashes live its wonted fires.
For ye, who mindful of my honours dead,</br>Do in your lines my hapless tale relate,</br>If by kind feeling to your office led,</br>Some crazy patriot shall inquire my fate,
Ah, woe is me!  "some wicked wit will tell,</br>Oft have we seen him, ere the evening fall,</br>Brushing with hasty steps along Pall-mall,</br>To meet LLOYD WARDLE at the House's call.

"There to the nodding Members luckless wights,</br>In hackney'd strains till midnight would he preach;</br>'Bout Magna Charta, and the Bill of Rights,</br>And prate of things far, far, beyond his reach.
"To prison sent, he swore they us'd him ill,</br>The room was powerless, as all should see;</br>The trial came, and British Judges still</br>Refus'd to change the House's just decree.
"And now with judgment due in sad dismay,</br>He sees himself consign'd to public scorn;</br>Approach and read, if thou can'st read the lay</br>Penn'd in the POST, to Jacobins a thorn."
EPITAPH.</br>Here hides his head, now humbled to the earth,</br>A man to John Horne and his Faction known;</br>Fair talents never smil'd upon his birth,</br>And disappointment mark'd him for her own.

Large were his wishes, but his lot severe,</br>To TOOKE, he ow'd his fortune and reverse;</br>He gain'd from JOHN, 'twas all his portion — shame,</br>John gained from him, 'twas all he wished — his purse.
No further seek his merits to disclose,</br>Or draw his frailties from their dread abode;</br>Where they have met the awful test he chose,</br>The judgment of his country and his God.</br>
